To format your text as code, enter three backticks on the first line, press Enter for a new line, paste your code, press Enter again for another new line, and lastly three more backticks. [Here's an example](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/awesome-automations/hassbot-data/master/format.gif)

Don't forget you can edit your post rather than repeatedly posting the same thing.

**For over 15 lines** you must use a code share site such as <https://www.codepile.net/> (pick _YAML_ for the language) or <https://paste.debian.net/> (pick _YAML_ for the language).

Welcome to the Home Assistant Discord.

Please remember to read <#331130181102206976> and the welcome message that the bot (that'd be me) DMd you.

Every channel has a topic that explains what's on topic, and provides other information. Many also have pinned messages that can help you.

When you're done reading this, head over to <#397426163649216512> and say hi.

Please use a code share site to share code or logs, for example:

* <https://www.codepile.net/> (select _YAML_ as the language)
* <https://paste.debian.net/> (select _YAML_ as the language)
* <https://hastebin.com/> (sometimes may not allow you to save)

Please don't use Pastebin, since it can randomly add spaces to the main view. Please also don't share text as images since it makes it harder for people to help you. Remember that others may have colour blindness, impaired vision, etc.

Z-Wave is a low power, low bandwidth, protocol for home automation devices - mostly sensors, switches, and light controls. The <#332357267364249621> channel has links to the most current guidance and documentation.

[The XY problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XY_problem) is asking about your attempted solution rather than your actual problem.

This leads to enormous amounts of wasted time and energy, both on the part of people asking for help, and on the part of those providing help.

The problem occurs when people get stuck on what they believe is the solution and are unable to step back and explain the issue in full.

If you want to test out your MQTT install from your pi, first install [the client](https://mosquitto.org/2013/01/mosquitto-debian-repository/) and then use the following command to subscribe to all topics on your server:
```shell
$ mosquitto_sub -h IP_ADDRESS -u 'pi' -P 'raspberry' -t '#' -v
```

If you're having problems with your updates to your configuration:
* Check the [troubleshooting steps](https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/troubleshooting/)
* Check your log file - remembering you may need to set [logger](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/logger#default) to `info` or `debug`
* Explain what the problem you're having is - [sharing](https://paste.ubuntu.com/) configuration, errors, and logs

A very simple yet powerful utility to help ease headaches when building up your Home Assistant configuration files.

Simply run this at your shell prompt to install hassctl:
```bash
$ sudo curl -o /usr/local/bin/hassctl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dale3h/hassctl/master/hassctl && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/hassctl
```
For more information, please visit the `hassctl` project page: <https://github.com/dale3h/hassctl>

You should automate, outside of Home Assistant, taking backups of your configuration, multiple times per day, using a tool that will track and store different versions, as well as creating a bootable backup if you're using a Raspberry Pi series computer. Options include rpi-clone (for bootable backups), rsnapshot (for backups within your home network), and rclone (for online backups).

Not sure which install you're using? If you have [`system_health`](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/system_health) enabled you can check [_Configuration -> Info_](https://my.home-assistant.io/redirect/info) -> _Installation Type_, or see the following.

* If you bought the Home Assistant Blue, flashed an image, or booted a VM with an image you're using <#330990055533576204>

* If you installed Linux and then ran a script to install HA _and_ have add-ons then you have <#330944238910963714>

* If you're running `docker` commands or use a Docker manager and have _no add-ons_ or Supervisor then you have <#449717345808547842>

* Finally, if you use `pip` to install or upgrade you have <#551864459891703809>

5 Rules for better support:

1. Be very specific about the issue/problem you are facing (a problem clearly stated is a problem half solved)
2. Absolutely NO negative comments about individuals, developers or the community
3. Read the [documentation](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/) (RTFM). It is an open source product, you are allowed to contribute, but not whine
4. Every setup is unique in its own way. Share your config, code, logs and other relevant info via https://hasteb.in/ or https://paste.ubuntu.com/ - don't post walls of text in the channels
5. Keep the channel live by being friendly, offer help where you can, learn when you can't!
6. Remember to review <#331130181102206976>

To enable packages, add `packages: !include_dir_named packages` to your `configuration.yaml` so that it looks similar to this:
```yaml
homeassistant:
  name: Home
  latitude: !secret home_latitude
  ...
  packages: !include_dir_named packages
```
***Important:** The `packages:` line **must** be nested under `homeassistant:`!*

For more information on packages, please refer to the packages docs: <https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/packages/>

[YAML](https://home-assistant.io/docs/configuration/yaml/) is the mark up language used by Home Assistant, consistent indenting (two spaces per level) is key. [Here](http://thomasloven.com/blog/2018/08/YAML-For-Nonprogrammers/) is a primer, and [this](https://yaml-multiline.info/) explains multi-line templates. For validating YAML see [YAML Lint](http://www.yamllint.com/).
[Glance cards](https://www.home-assistant.io/lovelace/glance/) are very compact

The monster card was repalced by [auto entities](https://github.com/thomasloven/lovelace-auto-entities) which is a magical type of card. Because it's dynamic if you're smart about it, you can have one card that adapts and that you don't need to touch when adding new entities & sensors to your setup. Supports both inclusion and exclusion filters with wildcard for `entity_id`

* You can test them in _Developer tools_ -> _Templates_

[Don't ask to ask](https://dontasktoask.com/), just ask your question. Then people can answer when they're around.

When you do ask a question, try to provide as much background detail as possible. Ask yourself these questions first so that others don't have to:

1. *What version of the Home Assistant are you running? (remember, _last_ isn't a version)*
2. *What exactly are you trying to do that won't work?*
3. *Is the problem uniform or erratic?*
4. *What's the exact error message?*
5. *When did it arise?*
6. *What exactly don't you \"get\"?*
7. *Can you [share](https://paste.ubuntu.com/) sample code, ideally with line errors where the error occurs?*

**Before You Ask**
[How To Ask Questions The Smart Way](<http://www.catb.org/esr/faqs/smart-questions.html)

Before asking a technical question in our channels, please do the following:

1. Try to find an answer by searching the [archives of the forum](https://community.home-assistant.io/)
2. Try to find an answer by searching [the Web](https://www.google.com/)
3. Try to find an answer by reading [the manual](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/)
4. Try to find an answer by reading [the FAQ](https://www.home-assistant.io/faq/)
5. Try to find an answer by inspection or experimentation.
6. Try to find an answer by asking a skilled friend.
7. If you're a programmer, try to find an answer by reading [the source code](https://github.com/home-assistant/home-assistant)

When you ask your question, display the fact that you have done these things first; this will help establish that you're not being a lazy sponge and wasting people's time. Better yet, display what you have learned from doing these things. We like answering questions for people who have demonstrated they can learn from the answers.

Please use [imgur](https://imgur.com/) or other image sharing web sites, and share the link here.

Image posting is blocked in most channels to discourage people from sharing text as images. Sharing text as images assumes that everybody sees the world as you do, which isn't the case. Some people are colour blind, or have visual impairment that means they can't make sense of an image of text.

Help us help you. To quickly explain your environment please specify V/E/F

- Version - Which version of Home Assistant are you running?
  Example: 0.84.3, 0.82.0, 0.85.beta.1
- Enviroment - How are you running Home Assistant?
  Example: venv, venv-WSL, docker, hassio, native
- Frontend: - Which kind of frontend configuration are you using?
  Example: auto, manual, yaml, legacy (not lovelace)

Examples: 0.84.3/venv/yaml

***Always*** run the configuration check *command* when you make changes. Don't trust the UI check - it misses some problems.

* HAOS & Supervised use [`ha core check`](https://www.home-assistant.io/common-tasks/os/#configuration-check)
* Container uses [`docker` commands](https://www.home-assistant.io/common-tasks/container/#configuration-check)
* Core requires you to [activate the venv first](https://www.home-assistant.io/common-tasks/core/#configuration-check)

```
Or [the raw data](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/awesome-automations/hassbot-data/master/commands.json)

**404** Error for docker usually is a result of one of these things:

- The image tag you are trying to use does not exist (if this is the case you will see the word 'manifest' in the error)

- There is not enough space left on the device to download the new container.

As an alternative to HA built-in bluetooth tracking, [the monitor script](https://github.com/andrewjfreyer/monitor) uses separate devices, usually [Pi Zeroes](https://www.raspberrypi.org/products/raspberry-pi-zero/), to track bluetooth devices.
It uses MQTT topics to relay device status messages to HA. See [this forum thread](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/monitor-reliable-multi-user-distributed-bluetooth-occupancy-presence-detection/68505) for more.

There is also an [add-on](https://github.com/Limych/addon-presence-monitor) available for it.

[This forum post](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/how-to-help-us-help-you-or-how-to-ask-a-good-question/114371) covers the things we need to know to help you. Key things are the version of _Home Assistant_ you're running, how you installed it (Home Assistant OS, Supervised, Container, Core), the exact component you're having problems with (eg _Nest climate_ rather than _climate_), and details of the problem (ideally with any error message in full).

[Home Assistant](https://www.home-assistant.io/hassio/) (previously called Hass.io) is _one of_ the ways you can [install](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/) **Home Assistant Core**. You're still running Home Assistant Core.

There are three Zigbee options with Home Assistant (regardless of how you install it). These are:

[deCONZ](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/deconz/) is relatively stable and mature with its own UI (and [Discord server](https://discord.gg/RNTwa6d)). It can run in an add-on, in a Docker container, or natively. Only the ConBee range of sticks and RaspBee GPIO boards are supported. Known working devices are documented, and how to request support for a new device is documented too (you can't add unsupported devices yourself).

[zha](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/zha/) is actively developed as part of Home Assistant Core, using the zigpy stack, the UI also being part of Home Assistant. The EmberZNet based sticks are recommended (though the HUSBZB-1 uses an older chipset), but there [are other options](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/zha#known-working-zigbee-radio-modules). There is no list of supported devices, as any standards compliant device should work. Devices that require extra support are listed, and adding unsupported devices is documented.

[Zigbee2MQTT](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/) is very actively developed and can run in an add-on, in a Docker container, and natively. As of 1.15 has a native UI, and it also uses MQTT for control and configuration. It supports [mostly TI based sticks](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/information/supported_adapters.html), with the recommended option being the [CC2652 based sticks](https://discord.com/channels/330944238910963714/551843655682490399/834770749012181052). If you want to use an EmberZNet stick see [this issue](https://github.com/Koenkk/zigbee-herdsman/issues/319#issuecomment-789757269). The known working devices are [well documented](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/information/supported_devices.html) (which usually includes how to pair them so you don't have to find the manual), and adding unsupported devices is also documented.

Looking for advice about a device to buy? Remember to provide guidance on:
* Which country you're in
* What your budget is
* What protocols you prefer (eg Zigbee, WiFi, Z-Wave)
* Any features you want (such as power monitoring, dimming, etc)
Hass.io was the old name for the appliance like install option, that _uses_ Docker. It was renamed in January 2020 and is now called _Home Assistant OS_ (see <#330990055533576204>).

Integrations _integrate_ Home Assistant with devices or services, or provide functionality within Home Assistant.

Add-ons provide additional software or services, which an integration could possibility integrate with. Add-ons are for Home Assistant OS and Supervised only, other install methods can install software other ways.

Running Home Assistant in a venv on Windows isn't recommended. Not all integrations may work, because some Python packages aren't available. You should consider [using Docker](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/docker/#windows) instead, or running on a Linux host.

[deCONZ](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/deconz) by dresden elektronik is a software that communicates with ConBee/RaspBee Zigbee gateways and exposes Zigbee devices that are connected to the gateway. Our <#551843655682490399> channel is a good place to ask about using it with Home Assistant, but they also have their own [Discord server](https://discord.gg/RNTwa6d).

[ESPHome](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/esphome/) is a system to control your ESP8266/ESP32, with a [native integration](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/esphome/) for Home Assistant.

You can find their [documentation here](https://esphome.io/), and get help with ESPHome itself here in the <#444529271806099486> channel (<#672220541343760384> for the Home Assistant side integration with it). They also have their own [Discord server too](https://discord.gg/KhAMKrd).

[AppDaemon](https://appdaemon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) is a loosely coupled, multithreaded, sandboxed python execution environment for writing automation apps. It uses the Home Assistant API (or MQTT) to communicate with HA. You can get help at [their Discord server](https://discord.gg/Mx5qafB).

[Zigbee2MQTT](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/) is a Zigbee gateway that uses MQTT to communicate with HA and supports a range of TI chipset based controllers. Our <#551843655682490399> channel is a good place to ask about using it with Home Assistant, but they also have their own [Discord server](https://discord.gg/NyseBeK).
Some [integrations](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations) are added with YAML, some in the UI. Check the documentation for your integration to see which method it uses.
A learning experience is one of those things that says, _'You know that thing you just did? Don't do that.'_

An add-on is a Docker container with tweaks to allow it to be configured in the Supervisor UI. It is only available in the Supervised installs (<#330990055533576204> and <#330944238910963714>) since if you've used any other install method you're able to install software already.
Various settings are hidden unless your user profile has _Advanced mode_ enabled. These include some add-ons, the Lovelace _Resources_ menu, server control options, and more.
You can find his config lurking [in the darkness](https://github.com/atxbyea/HA-Config).

To test an automation there's three stages you can follow. Testing the action, the condition and action, and the whole automation:

1) Use _Configuration_ -> _Automations_ to find the automationand then push _Run Actions_. If this fails your problem is in the `action:` section, and details should be found in your log file
2) Use _Developer tools_ -> _Services_ and call `automation.trigger` on the automation with `skip_condition: false`. If the first passes but this fails then the problem is in your `condition:` block
3) Use _Developer tools_ -> _States_ to find the trigger entity, click the name, then change the state (at the top) to something that'll trigger the automation before pushing _Set State_. If this fails then the problem is with your `trigger:` section, or the automation is turned off (you can check that in _Developer tools -> States_).

You can also see [this section in the docs](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/automation/troubleshooting/) and with HA 2021.4 onwards [debug automations](https://www.home-assistant.io/blog/2021/04/07/release-20214/#automation-debugging).
Please don't say _I have an error_ or describe an error. Share the whole actual error message so we can help you.

Not sure which install method to use, here's a [simple summary](https://www.home-assistant.io/faq/ha-vs-hassio/):

* [Home Assistant](https://www.home-assistant.io/hassio/installation/): All in one solution with the ability to install other software though the UI (called add-ons), and manage backups in the UI (called snapshots). Installs as an image or on top of Debian/Ubuntu.
* [Docker](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/docker/): For those already at comfortable with running on Docker. You install other software and manage backups yourself. Consider another option if you're using Windows or macOS.
* [venv](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/installation/raspberry-pi/): For those Linux admins or other crazy folks who want to run bare metal. You do everything, including rebuilding your venv with new Python versions. Don't try this method on Windows.

TL/DR: Use what works for you.

Buy something CC2652 based. [This list](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/information/supported_adapters.html) is a good one, both Tube and Electrolama have been proven to have excellent customer service. The current generation of EZSP sticks ([see here for some](https://github.com/Koenkk/zigbee-herdsman/issues/319#issuecomment-789757269)) are also a good choice for ZHA.

Anything CC2530 or CC2531 based should be avoided - they're old, slow, and only suitable for a dozen or so devices. The Sonoff ZBbridge isn't advised since it uses WiFi (built in interference causing stability/reliability issues), and the HUSBZB-1 uses an older chipset so should be avoided.

Finally, the ConBee range are fine with deCONZ, but experience with ZHA and Zigbee2MQTT appears to be mixed.

Generally, don't tag people to ask for help - it comes across as bad manners, you’re demanding somebody answers you. It’s different if you’re thanking somebody, obviously. If you do tag somebody keep it polite and respectful. Remember that everybody is a volunteer, and nobody _has_ to help you, and people may block you.

Similarly, please don’t DM (direct message) people asking for help. It also comes across as demanding, and means that others can’t learn from what you do.

Finally, please keep tagging people in replies to a minimum. That too can become annoying very quickly and should be used only when it's necessary (such as if it's been a long time, or there's multiple conversations going on). **Oh boy!** :scream:

`database disk image is malformed` tells you that your database file has been corrupted :cry:
But do not worry, there is an easy fix :tada:
1. Delete the `home-assistant_v2.db` file in the same folder as `configuration.yaml`
2. Restart Home Assistant.

_Sidenote: this will cause you to lose all your history, but it's broken anyway, so just do it._

To enable debug for the deCONZ integration in Home-Assistant, add the following to your configuration.yaml:```yaml
logger:
  default: info
  logs:
    pydeconz: debug
    homeassistant.components.deconz: debug
```

If you have a feature request for the frontend you can open [one here](https://github.com/home-assistant/frontend/issues), for Home Assistant itself please [post on the forum](https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests/13). All other feature requests should be made to the developer of that custom card/component.

There is no universal _best_ [weather integration](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations#weather). Which one works best _for you_ depends on where you live - try them all and see which is generally the most accurate.

There is no universal _best_ anything. There's always trade-offs, you need to explain:

* Your priorities/desired features
* Where in the world you are
* Your budget
* Any protocols that you'd prefer (eg Zigbee) or want to avoid (eg Zigbee)

[Secure Web Application Gateway](https://docs.linuxserver.io/general/swag) aka SWAG - is the easiest way of setting up a reverse proxy server with SSL (using Certbot and LetsEncrypt) for your Docker based install. See [their documentation](https://docs.linuxserver.io/general/swag) on it, and if you get stuck they also have [a Discord server](https://discord.gg/YWrKVTn) and [forum](https://docs.linuxserver.io/general/swag).

If `tts` isn't working in your media players (and on a Google device at most you get a _bloop_), then the problem is most likely down to SSL. If you're using SSL in HA make sure that your `external_url` is correctly set, and that `internal_url` matches it. Alternatively set [`base_url`](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/tts#base_url) in the `tts` integration to your external SSL URL.

Why use the [sun elevation trigger](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/automation/trigger/#sun-elevation-trigger) or [condition](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/scripts/conditions/#sun-elevation-condition) rather than a time offset from sunset or sunrise? Because the elevation more consistently relates to the light level than a fixed time offset. An hour before sunset is very different light levels on the longest day than the shortest day, for example.
No, there isn't actually a bot command for everything

The CC2531 and CC2530 sticks are cheap for a reason. They're fine for testing, but do yourself a favour and buy something better.

What something better? Anything CC2652 based ([see here for some](https://www.zigbee2mqtt.io/information/supported_adapters.html)) or the current generation EZSP ([see here for some](https://github.com/Koenkk/zigbee-herdsman/issues/319#issuecomment-789757269)).

The Sonoff ZBbridge isn't advised since it uses WiFi, and the HUSBZB-1 uses an older chipset so should be avoided.

People (and other sentient or vaguely intelligent beings) aren't waiting here for your questions, ready to leap upon them the moment they appear. Have a little patience. Keep in mind that repeatedly posting to get attention is against the rules (flooding) and can get you muted or banned.

You can report spam [Directly to Discord](https://support.discord.com/hc/en-us/articles/360000291932-How-to-Properly-Report-Issues-to-Trust-Safety) and they can act against the account. On this server we can ban the user if you provide a screenshot of the spam and the user's handle (eg @spammer#123) in <#397426163649216512>.

The _States_ screen (under _Developer Tools_) is your truth table for what Home Assistant knows. Every entity is listed here, along with the state the system knows (instead of the translated value you see elsewhere), and all attributes.

If you're using any of the install methods that use Docker (basically everything but HA Core) then Home Assistant runs in a container that only shares a limited number of folders with the host (or add-ons if you use those). If you're working with files outside of `/config/` or certain other folders then those only exist _in that container_ and other containers won't see them.

This is commonly experienced when using shell scripts or camera snapshot services, when you create a file in `/root` or `/tmp` and then can't find it in another container.
If you bought a Home Assistant Blue and are having trouble with the install itself, or questions about the Blue, please see <#330990055533576204>.

If you have questions about the security bulletin the only place to find the answers is in [the blog post](https://www.home-assistant.io/blog/2021/01/14/security-bulletin/). If the information isn't there we can't tell you, because we don't know either.

PS: We also don't know when it'll be updated.

If you have any questions, they're best asked on the linked [forum thread](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/security-bulletin/268456/).

For Zigbee2MQTT any CC2652p (or CC2652) based stick is a good choice. Those are also a good choice for ZHA, which also supports the EmberZNet sticks ([see here for some details](https://github.com/Koenkk/zigbee-herdsman/issues/319#issuecomment-789757269)). Don't pick the cheap CC2530/CC2531 sticks, and avoid the Sonoff Zigbee bridge since Zigbee and WiFi aren't friends. If you're not using deCONZ avoid the ConBee and RaspBee devices.

There are three sections to an automation:

* [**`trigger`**](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/automation/trigger/): When _any_ of these _becomes true_ the automation starts processing.
* [**`condition`**](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/automation/condition/): These are checked after a `trigger` starts the processing, and must _be true_ for the automation to continue.
* [**`action`**](https://www.home-assistant.io/docs/scripts/): This is the part that does something, and can also include further conditions.

Don't use HassWP, it's unsupported and unsupportable. It runs Home Assistnat directly in Windows, which means many things won't work, and relies on the developer to keep it updated (which often isn't the case).

Just use a [supported installation approach](https://www.home-assistant.io/installation#compare-installation-methods) and you'll have less pain.

If you have an open PR and are waiting for feedback, please be patient and do not beg for a review. We have a huge backlog of PRs at any given moment and while the core reviewers do their best to get to PRs in a timely fashion, what's considered timely has grown over time. The best way that you can help us get to your PRs faster is to look at other PRs and add your reviews - even though PRs need a core reviewer for a formal approval, reviews from the community will help reduce the back and forth and make reviews easier for the core team.

With all that being said, if you have an open PR that gets a stale label added to it, add a comment so the bot will remove the label, and THEN you can post here asking for help since we want to make sure that PRs don't get auto-closed because of a lack of feedback.

[Schedy](https://hass-apps.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apps/schedy/) is a highly-configurable, comfortable to use multi-purpose scheduler for Home Assistant that controls different types of actors such as switches and thermostats based on powerful rules while still facilitating manual intervention at any time.

The goal is to provide an easy solution for conventional scheduling (e.g. by time of day and day of week) while leaving advanced users plenty of room for customization with arbitrarily complex rules.

SD cards die - the more you write to them, the sooner they die. You can get a longer life with an Industrial SD card, or ones designed for 24x7 camera recording.

You're better off moving off the SD cards though, either use an SSD or replace that Pi with just about any 64 bit capable system from the last decade.
